conversations.content: After the Paradise Incident Northern Church HQ Regina's Lab
I move my woodland archer two squares forward and diagonally left.
Aaand...I'll move my sorceress princess three squares forward. Take that!
I'm afraid I predicted that. I put your sacred dragonlord in check with my stone trebuchet.
Oh, darn it! I left the right side wide open without even realizing it.
Oof. You schooled me good, Regina. I thought I might have a chance with the southern-style rules I picked up in the Halidom, but it didn't make a difference.
Sound logic, but the basics are the same as the northern style. If a slight rule shift were enough to unnerve me, I'd have no right to call myself a commander of anything.
Well, I think you're incredible—I mean, even Nevin has trouble winning against you! Maybe I'll stumble into a fluke victory at some point, but I sort of doubt it.
Heh. Well, keep working at it. Don't let Nevin stay ahead of you.
In any event, I appreciate the break. You just came out here to make a report and I ended up taking all of your time.
But thanks to that, I've chanced upon a way to improve an alchemy technique I was stuck on.
Oh, wow! I mean, I don't know a thing about alchemy, but I'm happy I was able to help someone as esteemed as you.
Oh. Um, yes, thank you.
Sorry. It's just a little weird to have one of your apostles call you ＂esteemed.＂
Huh? Why?
When I first came here, I didn't think I'd ever see a day where apostles respected me, much less held me in high regard.
You missed it because you were training abroad with Gabriel, but those were some pretty tough days for me.
It could not be helped. Back then, Regina was not acknowledged or accepted by the apostles, so it was only natural for their relationship to be a chilly one.
And you were just as chilly as they were in the beginning, Sandalphon. Everyone forsook me in those days.
This is so weird! I mean, by the time I was back from training, you and the other apostles were so tight it made me jealous.
There was a turning point for it—a certain incident which warmed the frosty relations between all.
What kind of incident?
Oh, I dunno. It's not very interesting.
Okay, now I'm REALLY curious.
Look, I'm heading off to infiltrate enemy territory soon, and knowing this story would be a huge morale boost, soooo...
That's low, Pinon. ...But all right.
This was about three years ago, right after I'd taken up my post as commander. There was an incident in the city—one big enough to shock everyone to their cores.
Curiously enough, it was perpetrated by the same people you're about to infiltrate: the military-ruled nation of Rozcimea.
Three Years Ago  The Holy City of Grams Northern Church Headquarters
Hey there. I'm Regina, and starting today, I'll be your commander. I come from the Curia's alchemy research team, and will continue to hold my research position.
I don't leave the lab much, so on-site work is a bit strange to me, but I'll do my best. Anyway, it's good to meet all of you.
In other words... you're a complete amateur? I know the archbishop values your tactical mind, but that doesn't mean you're ready for actual fieldwork.
That's a reasonable concern. But so long as the battlefield is my game board and our forces are my pieces, I don't intend to make a single miscalculation.
We're your pawns, huh? Well, Papa Bear's at least looking forward to working with you.

Though the apostles' dissatisfaction with my new appointment was clear, I'm a lady who prioritizes our mission objectives. So long as we did our work and did it well, I wasn't going to make an effort to get all buddy-buddy.
So although they all obeyed my instructions, there was a certain distance between us. Whatever our relationship was, it certainly wasn't built on a foundation of trust.
And that's when the incident happened...
Rozcimea dispatched assassins to kill Auspex Origa on a prayer day?!
Indeed. The guards apprehended one of the curs in the city earlier today.
They're likely targeting the days when she heads to the Second Cathedral, where there are fewer guards.
Well, this is a piece of bad news. And you said ＂one＂ of them. I take it there are more of these assassins roaming the city even as we speak?
Most likely. We're questioning the one we detained, but he does not seem inclined to speak on the matter.
The Auspex must be protected at all costs. I want you and your people to assist with the investigation and security as well. We'll use every resource we have to protect her.
I already have a plan, Your Eminence. But I'm going to need support and—
A ＂plan＂? I have neither the time nor the forces to spare for Basel's blasted pups. I ordered you to investigate and protect.
My apologies, Your Eminence. I shall see your will done.
*sigh* I'd rather not get involved in a factional dispute, but...I suppose it's time for this ＂blasted pup＂ to go ask the archbishop for some help.
I see. Will you convene the apostles at the same time?
There's no time—we're already one step behind. We'll give them orders on-site and have them work as fast as they can.
Every second counts. Sandalphon. Now please relay the orders.
...Very well.
We're already swamped with problems, and Rozcimea is no land of fools—but I have no intention of losing this game.
I'll use every measure at my fingertips to deliver stellar results!
The tidings are grim. We remain in the dark on the numbers and composition of our enemies in the Holy City. All we know is that they mean to strike at the Auspex.
With the Auspex visiting the Second Cathedral, it seems likely our enemies will gather in the central district— along with uncountable residents.
We've already implemented strict security, but if a battle were to occur there, there would be a high probability of civilian casualties.
Don't worry, I'm aware. And given Rozcimea's military strength, I doubt this is limited to just a few assassins serving as scouts.
I've laid plans to deal with all of those concerns. We'll see this done, and  done well.
More importantly, have you ascertained the whereabouts of the apostles?
Yes. They are all presently accompanied by their angels in Grams—with the exception of Pinon, who is off training.
Good. In that case, we'll have each apostle commence operations.
The moves have already been decided, so you just need to send the orders.
...Very well.
I bring orders from Regina: Each apostle will move to their designated location, then identify and engage the enemy immediately.
I repeat: Each apostle will move to their designated location, then identify and engage the enemy immediately. Your locations are as follows...
＂Identify and engage immediately＂? Somehow I don't think they're going to come out of hiding at our convenience.
It's an unclear instruction; I think she may need to lose points.
Regardless, orders are orders. We'll head to our locations at once.
Well, now. They burst in with a transmission out of nowhere, and it turns out to be a doozy.
So they're targeting the Auspex, eh? These are quite the bold troublemakers we have here.
Even so, can't say I was expecting these orders. Does the commander think she's playing chess with real people here?
I guess being moved around the board like a bunch of pieces is just part of the job, huh? Fun times ahead.
Would it not make more sense—and cause less chaos—if we simply used the Auspex as bait and laid a trap for the enemy where she is going to be?
Orders are orders, Michael, so let's give this a chance before we start considering full-on sedition.
Well, I guess we should get this party started. This is where we've been posted, so let's start tracking down the enemy.
That would be easier if we knew what the enemy looked like. They could be disguised right in front of us for all we know.
In which case, Ryszarda, it's time for you to lean on the ol' intuition!
We know most of the people in this area, so just keep an eye out for anyone who seems unfamiliar or overly nervous.
Also, you can try thinking like the enemy. If you were going undercover here, how would you try to blend in?
Well, if it were me and I needed to move around the city in secret...
I'd try to lose myself in the crowds and maintain an appearance of calm while I watched and assessed the situation. JUST LIKE THIS GUY!
Blargh!
He's got the Rozcimea coat of arms at the base of his neck! Nice work, Ryszarda! Now let's run the villain down.
Right! I shall administer Her authority!
Tch! Can't believe the apostles have already been called into play.
I need to inform my comrades at once!
Too bad I'm putting you down here. Haaah!
Such...strength...
Rrrgh! Don't get too cocky, apostle. Time for a little...FOG of war!
*cough* *hack* Smoke!
He got away! I hate it when they see an apostle and jump right to the sneaky stuff.
If we'd had another apostle around, we could have chased that creep down.
I'm sorry. I'm just useless.
Wrong! The enemy just got one over on us. But at least we fulfilled Regina's orders to the letter.
Anyway, we'll never catch that assassin now, so let's report back and find out what our next orders are.
All right...
Thank you for your reports. Each of you are to stand by for further orders.
I have received word from the apostles around the Holy City. They all intercepted enemies and failed to apprehend them.
They all came into contact? Good.
How is that good? The enemies escaped.
Everything is going exactly as I planned. Each apostle is serving a purpose.
We'll move to the next phase right away. Please send the orders.
...Very well.
I have your current orders from Regina. Each apostle is to move to a new designated location and continue searching for the enemy. That is all.
So we're still going to be split up?!
Sure seems that way, given our destinations.
Even if we find another thug, we'll just  go through the same song and dance before losing them again!
I doubt she'd have gotten the job from the archbishop if she were THAT incompetent.
For the time being, we should just grit our teeth and follow orders.
This strategy doesn't make the grade. Is she even trying to protect the Auspex?
And what does a laboratory researcher know about field work like ours, anyway?
You'll find yourself out of a job if you keep talking like that, Faris. Whatever Regina's background, she's the rightful commander of the apostles.
I am aware of that. And yet...
Since it's clear we're dealing with multiple enemies hiding in the shadows, would it not make more sense to set an ambush?
What say you, Basileus? Are you satisfied with Regina's directives?
My satisfaction doesn't matter. We have orders, so we need to obey them and be ready to deal with any unforeseen issues.
Which is a long-winded way of saying you do not trust her orders.
Trust doesn't matter either. Now come on.
No enemy contact this time... It's eerily quiet.
It must simply mean there weren't any enemies in our area. This part of the city doesn't have much in it to begin with, besides the east gate. Few live here.
Sandalphon, this is Uriel. No sign of the enemy here in the northeast district. How are the other regions faring?
I have also received the same report from Raphael, Michael, and Ramiel.
What? EVERY apostle failed to find an enemy?
Incorrect. There have been eyewitness reports in the other areas where apostles have been positioned. My understanding is that work to track them is ongoing.
Regina says that the operation is being carried out perfectly and there is no need for concern. You are to wait for your next set of orders.
Standby again, is it? Well, I suppose that's simply how it is. Hopefully we'll get some new orders very soon.
No. I'm done waiting.
What do you mean?
One misstep I can accept, but two? No. The Auspex's life is at stake, and if we keep blundering around like a bunch of idiots, she's going to lose it.
These orders will only lead to misery. I'm going to the Second Cathedral.
I'll protect the Auspex from her enemies myself if that's what it takes!
Faris, wait! Oh, for the love of... Sandalphon, this is Uriel! I'm pursuing Faris to the Second Cathedral!
Regina, I have a message from Uriel. Faris has disobeyed orders and made for the Auspex's location.
Uriel is currently pursuing, which means  the northeastern district of the city is currently defenseless.
That's fine; leave him be. My strategy is still intact.
Am I to understand you will permit this insubordination merely because you find him difficult to manage?
All I said is that we can leave him be to act freely for now. The game isn't ended if a single piece moves out of place.
Understood. However, I would like to offer you some advice.
And what is that?
You have a habit of conflating reality with play. Simulations are necessary training for tactics, but life is no game.
If you treat others as mere pieces on a board and never build trust with them, your elaborate strategies will collapse.
This breach of orders by Faris could well lead to that breakdown. You should understand the individuals you work with and take pragmatic measures to...
Wait. I'm getting a report from Michael. ...Yes, Michael? What is it?
Seems there was an explosion in the northeast district. A very large one.
I think Faris and Uriel are patrolling there. Should we leave it to them?
Unfortunately, they've left the district and are headed for the Auspex.
Disobeying orders, mmm? I see.
Why do I feel like the enemy was just waiting for a chance to unleash this kind of chaos the moment we broke ranks?
Sorry to ask this, Sandalphon, but can you pass a message to the commander?
＂Looks like your strategy has gone awry. Are we still in a good place?＂
＂Either way, Basileus will follow orders to the end, so we await further instruction.＂
The situation has changed significantly, Regina. After Faris abandoned his post, the northeastern district of the city was overrun by enemy reinforcements.
Michael and Basileus are awaiting orders. What is the next step for them?
There is no next step.
Then you have waived your right of leadership? Very well. I will set to work on restructuring the chain of command to—
Hang on, Sandalphon. Not having a next move doesn't mean I'm forfeiting.
I've already locked down checkmate. THAT'S why I have no further orders for the apostles.
Still, if it's orders they want...
...I have our next orders, Nevin.
Oh yeah? What is it? Maybe something that ol' Papa Bear can play an active and VERY cool role in?
Apparently Regina has nothing else to say to us, so we are free to act as we please.
She's not even bothering? Well, that's convenient, I suppose.
Hell, we've already started acting without orders anyway.
And we're not the only ones, either— seems like everyone other than Michael and Basileus is heading for the northeast district.
Especially Faris, who was supposed to be there to begin with. He started rushing back at full speed after the incident.
Yeah, that was one heck of an explosion. I bet Faris is kicking himself right now. Poor guy's face is probably even paler than usual.
Still, I don't think he was mistaken to head to the Second Cathedral to protect the Auspex.
In any event, if Michael's report that a force with magical weapons is incoming is correct, we'll need multiple apostles at the ready.
We will reach the location shortly. Be prepared to work with your comrades the moment we arrive.
You know I'll be on the ball— I was taught by you, after all.
It's party time for ol' Papa Bear! Now let's apply our brilliance to sorting out this nasty dilemma.
Gwaaaah!
Hrk... This is...madness...
Uh...is it me, or did somebody already come along and clobber these guys?
Attaaaaack! Destroy the villains who dare target our beloved Auspex!
Wait, so now the Templars are here? What the hell's going on?!
By the time we got here, the Templars had already surrounded the assassins.
Why would they just conveniently be... Wait, what happened to the assassins who got away from us?
...They were all here too. Uriel and I just finished rounding them up.
How did this happen?! We took every advantage of the apostles breaking from their plan. Why were the Templars here?!
You took the words right out of my mouth, my inept evildoer! But seriously, guys, what's the deal?
I have no idea.
You're saying the Templars are there and you've captured all the assassins? ...Just what is going on?
Told you it was checkmate.
Archbishop Basel managed to get it done just in time. This is great!
I demand an explanation.
We'd love to hear this as well.
Oh, Michael and Basileus. You were satisfied not going to the northeast district?
You gave orders saying we could act as we pleased. So if this was all part of your grand strategy, let's have you break it down for us.
Well, I suppose there's no reason for secrecy at this point.
Here's exactly what happened...
Now then, let me reveal the game. It all started a few hours ago when we received word there would be assassins targeting the Auspex.
At that point, my mission was to settle things without harm to the city— especially the heavily populated areas.
Right away, I thought of incorporating the Templars into my plan.
But when Graht refused to cooperate, I had to turn to the archbishop for a little backstage maneuvering.
Ah.
*sigh* I'd rather not get involved in a factional dispute, but...I suppose it's time for this ＂blasted pup＂ to go ask the archbishop for some help.
So even at that early hour you had already envisioned this final state of the game?
Yep! At any rate, if the Templars were going to act, I figured it would be best for us to operate under a unified strategy instead of doing our own separate thing.
But if I didn't choose a location where the Templars could act without restraint, I would fail to achieve the objective of avoiding harm to the city.
So you had them gather in the sparsely populated northeast district to help avoid any civilian casualties.
But the remaining question is how you got the ENEMIES to go there.
That's where we came in. I imagine the inexplicable positions you deployed us to were chosen specifically to herd our enemies?
That's right. When I suspected the assassins were acting as scouts, I gave them a convenient opening and lead them to the northeast district.
That's why I put four of you in locations designed to restrict enemy movement.
So, the apostles missing their chance to apprehend them wasn't a problem because the whole point was for the enemy to see the apostles?
Right. Furthermore, once the enemy saw you, I knew they'd be sensitive to any further movements.
Of course. And then you have Faris break off in a way that looks like nothing more than a violation of orders.
The enemies would seize that chance to gather in the northeast district and fall right into your trap.
I can't believe Faris disobeying orders was also part of your plan. I had no idea you saw through us all to that extent.
I'm not the type to sit down at the game board without understanding the people I'll be fighting with.
Before I came here, I obtained information on all of you from the archbishop. So yes, in my own way, I've come to understand who each of you are.
For example, Faris' tendency to score things tells me that he has a strong proclivity toward a perfect existence. He seeks perfection and abhors failure.
If he senses even the slightest possibility of failure, he is willing to act on his own authority to prevent it.
All the more so if it's an order from a commander with no field experience. Honestly, I saw that part coming from miles away.
And you used it to create an opening that would appear to be a good opportunity for the enemy.
It seems your analytical skills are not limited to understanding the abilities of the pieces under your command.
But do you know as much about Basileus as you do Faris?
Based on the materials I was given, I think I have a fair grasp of his behavior and the philosophy behind his actions.
And if that's the case, you must have had Ryszarda search near the main gate because you understood her intuition.
The assassins would be most likely found in the area of the city most suited for an incursion, after all. She ensured things would be set in motion early on.
That's about the size of it.
Your understanding clearly goes beyond the realm of mere analysis.
Is it truly possible to understand others so well with only superficial information?
Sandalphon, you told me that treating others as pieces in a game would cause my strategy to fall apart, remember?
But while I did build my strategy using the apostles as pieces, I also recognize that each piece is a unique individual.
Only a second-rate commander would completely disregard the emotions and predilections of the people under their command.
You managed to see right though the apostles' personalities and abilities. I don't know if you're socially brilliant or just socially awkward.
Regardless, it seems I will have to revise my valuation of you moving forward.
Right? We were looking down on you because we thought we couldn't trust you, and now we look like a bunch of chumps.
It's vexing to be played so artfully, yet I cannot deny that the mission was a smashing success.
I knew the commander wasn't any ordinary person right from the start! It was my intuition at work.
Looks like everyone's back.
Those Templars are real go-getters. Wasn't much for us to do in the end. Oh, and we caught most of that explanation, so no need to go over it again.
I suppose it's not so bad to get moved around a board by a brain like you. Happy to have you aboard, Regina.
Likewise. Although next time, I would appreciate it if you could reveal more of your game plan to us from the start.
I would trust in you more so we might carry out our missions to perfection.
It's a deal—and I very much look forward to working with all of you.
The Present  Northern Church HQ Regina's Lab
Wow! I can't believe there was such a  spectacular reason for all of them to be singing your praises!
Yeah, it was rough going for a bit, but it gave me a chance to get closer to the apostles.
Now that we've built up a good rapport, I get to busy myself working with a group of extremely talented individuals.
Can't say I love how they've come to idolize me since then, but I suppose I can get used to it.
You've mellowed quite a bit in the last three years, Regina.
Stop. I'm not so twisted as to dislike having people trust me.
If I'm going to repay their belief in me, the best way is to lead them to victory.
And I intend to devote myself fully to that plan. I hope you'll be willing to help me in that, Pinon?
Of course! I'd do anything for you!
We apostles will see our mission fulfilled under your direction. Just leave it to us!
Glad to hear it. And in that case, it's time to get you set up with your new directive.
You'll be taking part in a special strategy I've put together to prevent Satan's return.
